issue.title: How can I add a new implementation of one signature schme and run it with openssl?
issue.body:
I think I have succeeded building a new implementation of dilithium2(with arm_neon) in liboqs by changing some configurations, but I don't know how to use it in openssl, beacuse openssl does not have a algorithm name called "dilithium2_arm".

By the way, I see there are "dilithium2_ref" and "dilithium2_avx2" in liboqs, when we run 
`apps/openssl req -x509 -new -newkey <SIG> -keyout <SIG>_CA.key -out <SIG>_CA.crt -nodes -subj "/CN=oqstest CA" -days 365 -config apps/openssl.cnf
`
If <SIG> is dilithium2, which one will be used, is "dilithium2_ref" default? Then, how can we use "dilithium2_avx2"?

issue.title: How can I add a new implementation of one signature schme and run it with openssl?
issue.body:
I think I have succeeded building a new implementation of dilithium2(with arm_neon) in liboqs by changing some configurations, but I don't know how to use it in openssl, beacuse openssl does not have a algorithm name called "dilithium2_arm".

By the way, I see there are "dilithium2_ref" and "dilithium2_avx2" in liboqs, when we run 
`apps/openssl req -x509 -new -newkey <SIG> -keyout <SIG>_CA.key -out <SIG>_CA.crt -nodes -subj "/CN=oqstest CA" -days 365 -config apps/openssl.cnf
`
If `<SIG>` is dilithium2, which one will be used, is "dilithium2_ref" default? Then, how can we use "dilithium2_avx2"?

In short, my purpose is to add "dilithium2_arm" and use it  in openssl command.

Thanks very much if you can help~

comment.body:
> openssl does not have a algorithm name called "dilithium2_arm".

This is intentional: The name selects the algorithm, not a specific platform code base. 

> If <SIG> is dilithium2, which one will be used, is "dilithium2_ref" default? Then, how can we use "dilithium2_avx2"?

This is the right question: At the core of `liboqs` is the desire to always make available the most suitable implementation for a specific platform. Accordingly, AVX2 will be used if liboqs (and openssl) get built on a(n x86_64) platform supporting that CPU feature (or if it has been specifically requested at build time by [configuration](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Customizing-liboqs#OQS_OPT_TARGET)).

> I think I have succeeded building a new implementation of dilithium2(with arm_neon) in liboqs by changing some configurations

That is very good and it would be great for everyone if you'd consider contributing that to [liboqs](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs) via a PR: It then would flow automatically into the downstream projects like oqs-openssl (and get automatically used when openssl is built on such platform).

As there currently already is activity in the `liboqs` project to bring in ARM optimized code (see for example https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1117), your work/contribution there would be great.

If `<SIG>` is dilithium2, which one will be used, is "dilithium2_ref" default? Then, how can we use "dilithium2_avx2"?

comment.body:
Thanks to your reviewing!

If I understand rightly, after I build an arm implementation of dilithium2 in liboqs and when I run the openssl command with algorithm `dilithium2` in ARM platform, then it will automatically use the arm one instead of the ref one?

And of course, I am glad to contribute, but there are many problems have not solved, when I clear them all I will do it, thanks for your invitation.

issue.body:
I think I have succeeded building a new implementation of dilithium2(with arm_neon) in liboqs by changing some configurations, but I don't know how to use it in openssl, beacuse openssl does not have a algorithm name called "dilithium2_arm".

By the way, I see there are "dilithium2_ref" and "dilithium2_avx2" in liboqs, when we run 
`apps/openssl req -x509 -new -newkey <SIG> -keyout <SIG>_CA.key -out <SIG>_CA.crt -nodes -subj "/CN=oqstest CA" -days 365 -config apps/openssl.cnf
`
If `<SIG>` is dilithium2, which one will be used, is "dilithium2_ref" default? Then, how can we use "dilithium2_avx2"?

In short, my purpose is to add "dilithium2_arm" and use it  in openssl command.

Thanks very much if you can help~

comment.body:
> If I understand rightly, after I build an arm implementation of dilithium2 in liboqs and when I run the openssl command with algorithm dilithium2 in ARM platform, then it will automatically use the arm one instead of the ref one?

Correct -- if and when there is an ARM-optimized implementation for the specific algorithm available in `liboqs` (as it is already for Kyber: [See for example the code here facilitating that for the decaps operation](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8c5bab6a26e618853a1eb0ae22c986c3986b6480/src/kem/kyber/kem_kyber_512.c#L85-L100)).

> And of course, I am glad to contribute, but there are many problems have not solved, when I clear them all I will do it, thanks for your invitation.

Looking forward to that. OK to close this issue here for now?

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body:
@anhu Please check out the "alternative PR" #105: It works OK and supports all OQS algorithms. I chose a different way to patch the wireshark code such as to allow you to re-use this for WolfSSL: All that's needed is a suitable header file defining the names; see [qsc.h](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/mb-wiresharkregistry/qsc.h) as to how I'm proposing it for the OQS case. If you're OK with that, I'd suggest we close this PR and move #105 forward. Thanks again for the initiative and initial work!

@dstebila Please check out https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/pull/340 as to whether you're OK with the proposed way to provide the required OpenSSL information to Wireshark (and possibly other users of this general "name/ID mapping").

comment.body: Well it is our intention within the next month or so to add the ARM NEON implementation of Dilithium from PQClean (e.g. https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/tree/master/crypto_sign/dilithium2).  How is your implementation different?

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body:
Hi @baentsch , 
My original intention when reaching out to the OQS team was to show how easy it was to get wireshark to display the OIDs and codepoints and to encourage the OQS team to do an integration.  I think its safe to say I was successful so I will happily close this PR.  

Would you be willing to host another patch that builds on top of your wireshark work that switches to wolfSSL's naming convention?

issue.title: Wireshark
issue.body:
Building on https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-demos/pull/104 (thanks to @anhu) this is an OQS-enabled wireshark build-and-dockerize command set. This will remain in draft status until documentation has been refined and final contents are agreed.

For a quick test/avoiding the need to build it locally, the image is available at docker hub under the name "openquantumsafe/wireshark", i.e., it can be executed (on X11-based UNIX hosts) via 

```
docker run --net=host --privileged --env="DISPLAY" --volume="$HOME/.Xauthority:/root/.Xauthority:rw" openquantumsafe/wireshark
```

All feedback welcome (tagging explicity @anhu @dstebila ) and suggesting to continue the discussion from #104 below.

comment.body: I was able to run it successfully on an Ubuntu VM. I couldn't get the settings right on my Mac, but it might be more complicated to get a GUI from Docker showing up on macOS' X host, so don't worry about it.

issue.title: Added supported-platforms compile guards in the SIKE CMakeLists
issue.body:
Added compile guards to SIKE's CMakeLists file to avoid downstream preprocessor failures in config.h when building on unsupported platforms.

Fixes #1128.

comment.body: When looking the code change over I wonder whether it properly solves the issue: I _think_ that the SIKE logic this way would not become part of liboqs (and not be compiled, so probably solving the original issue) in the case of mipsel, BUT I'm afraid that the algorithm #defines would be out of step with the library then: Wouldn't it be more prudent to (also) disable all `OQS_ENABLE_KEM_sike*` #defines when an unsupported platform is encountered? Back to your question of having a real platform for testing, @christianpaquin .... The best I could offer to check for good is to try to set up a qemu-based mipsel Debian. Or alternatively, we could ask for a test-run of this code in the Debian build harness before closing this for good.

issue.title: Added supported-platforms compile guards in the SIKE CMakeLists
issue.body:
Added compile guards to SIKE's CMakeLists file to avoid downstream preprocessor failures in config.h when building on unsupported platforms.

Fixes #1128.

comment.body:
> When looking the code change over I wonder whether it properly solves the issue: I _think_ that the SIKE logic this way would not become part of liboqs (and not be compiled, so probably solving the original issue) in the case of mipsel, BUT I'm afraid that the algorithm #defines would be out of step with the library then: Wouldn't it be more prudent to (also) disable all `OQS_ENABLE_KEM_sike*` #defines when an unsupported platform is encountered? 

Oh, that seems like a more robust solution, good point Michael.

issue.title: Added supported-platforms compile guards in the SIKE CMakeLists
issue.body:
Added compile guards to SIKE's CMakeLists file to avoid downstream preprocessor failures in config.h when building on unsupported platforms.

Fixes #1128.

comment.body:
@baentsch, @dstebila, yeah, good idea. I added some code in the main CMakeLists. I left the guards in the SIKE CMakeLists; I'm not sure if this is redundant.

I'm about to disconnect for the long Thanksgiving weekend, so in the interest of creating the RC soon, feel free to take over. I'm not a liboqs build master :) so feel free to adjust this PR accordingly.
